rule.name: Black listed name "%s"
rule.description: Used when the name is listed in the black list (unauthorized names).

rule.name: %s name "%s" doesn't conform to %s
rule.description: Used when the name doesn't conform to naming rules associated to its type (constant, variable, class...).

rule.name: Missing %s docstring
rule.description: Used when a module, function, class or method has no docstring.Some special methods like __init__ doesn't necessary require a docstring.

rule.name: Empty %s docstring
rule.description: Used when a module, function, class or method has an empty docstring (it would be too easy ;).

rule.name: Consider changing "%s" to "%s"
rule.description: Used when a boolean expression contains an unneeded negation.

rule.name: Comparison to %s should be %s
rule.description: Used when an expression is compared to singleton values like True, False or None.

rule.name: Comparison should be %s
rule.description: Used when the constant is placed on the left side of a comparison. It is usually clearer in intent to place it in the right hand side of the comparison.

rule.name: Using type() instead of isinstance() for a typecheck.
rule.description: The idiomatic way to perform an explicit typecheck in Python is to use isinstance(x, Y) rather than type(x) == Y, type(x) is Y. Though there are unusual situations where these give different results.

rule.name: Consider using enumerate instead of iterating with range and len
rule.description: Emitted when code that iterates with range and len is encountered. Such code can be simplified by using the enumerate builtin.

rule.name: Consider iterating the dictionary directly instead of calling .keys()
rule.description: Emitted when the keys of a dictionary are iterated through the .keys() method. It is enough to just iterate through the dictionary itself, as in "for key in dictionary".

rule.name: Class method %s should have %s as first argument
rule.description: Used when a class method has a first argument named differently than the value specified in valid-classmethod-first-arg option (default to "cls"), recommended to easily differentiate them from regular instance methods.

rule.name: Metaclass method %s should have %s as first argument
rule.description: Used when a metaclass method has a first argument named differently than the value specified in valid-classmethod-first-arg option (default to "cls"), recommended to easily differentiate them from regular instance methods.

rule.name: Metaclass class method %s should have %s as first argument
rule.description: Used when a metaclass class method has a first argument named differently than the value specified in valid-metaclass-classmethod-first-arg option (default to "mcs"), recommended to easily differentiate them from regular instance methods.

rule.name: Class __slots__ should be a non-string iterable
rule.description: Used when a class __slots__ is a simple string, rather than an iterable.

rule.name: Line too long (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when a line is longer than a given number of characters.

rule.name: Too many lines in module (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when a module has too much lines, reducing its readability.

rule.name: Trailing whitespace
rule.description: Used when there is whitespace between the end of a line and the newline.

rule.name: Final newline missing
rule.description: Used when the last line in a file is missing a newline.

rule.name: Trailing newlines
rule.description: Used when there are trailing blank lines in a file.

rule.name: More than one statement on a single line
rule.description: Used when more than on statement are found on the same line.

rule.name: Unnecessary parens after %r keyword
rule.description: Used when a single item in parentheses follows an if, for, or other keyword.

rule.name: %s space %s %s %s
rule.description: Used when a wrong number of spaces is used around an operator, bracket or block opener.

rule.name: Mixed line endings LF and CRLF
rule.description: Used when there are mixed (LF and CRLF) newline signs in a file.

rule.name: Unexpected line ending format. There is '%s' while it should be '%s'.
rule.description: Used when there is different newline than expected.

rule.name: Wrong %s indentation%s%s.
rule.description: TODO

rule.name: Wrong spelling of a word '%s' in a comment:
rule.description: Used when a word in comment is not spelled correctly.

rule.name: Wrong spelling of a word '%s' in a docstring:
rule.description: Used when a word in docstring is not spelled correctly.

rule.name: Invalid characters %r in a docstring
rule.description: Used when a word in docstring cannot be checked by enchant.

rule.name: Multiple imports on one line (%s)
rule.description: Used when import statement importing multiple modules is detected.

rule.name: %s should be placed before %s
rule.description: Used when PEP8 import order is not respected (standard imports first, then third-party libraries, then local imports)

rule.name: Imports from package %s are not grouped
rule.description: Used when imports are not grouped by packages

rule.name: Import "%s" should be placed at the top of the module
rule.description: Used when code and imports are mixed

rule.name: Old-style class defined.
rule.description: Used when a class is defined that does not inherit from another class and does not inherit explicitly from "object". This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Do not use `len(SEQUENCE)` to determine if a sequence is empty
rule.description: Used when Pylint detects that len(sequence) is being used inside a condition to determine if a sequence is empty. Instead of comparing the length to 0, rely on the fact that empty sequences are false.
Used when a syntax error is raised for a module.

rule.name: Unrecognized file option %r
rule.description: Used when an unknown inline option is encountered.

rule.name: Bad option value %r
rule.description: Used when a bad value for an inline option is encountered.

rule.name: __init__ method is a generator
rule.description: Used when the special class method __init__ is turned into a generator by a yield in its body.

rule.name: Explicit return in __init__
rule.description: Used when the special class method __init__ has an explicit return value.

rule.name: %s already defined line %s
rule.description: Used when a function / class / method is redefined.

rule.name: %r not properly in loop
rule.description: Used when break or continue keywords are used outside a loop.

rule.name: Return outside function
rule.description: Used when a "return" statement is found outside a function or method.

rule.name: Yield outside function
rule.description: Used when a "yield" statement is found outside a function or method.

rule.name: Return with argument inside generator
rule.description: Used when a "return" statement with an argument is found outside in a generator function or method (e.g. with some "yield" statements). This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.3.

rule.name: Use of the non-existent %s operator
rule.description: Used when you attempt to use the C-style pre-increment orpre-decrement operator -- and ++, which doesn't exist in Python.

rule.name: Duplicate argument name %s in function definition
rule.description: Duplicate argument names in function definitions are syntax errors.

rule.name: Abstract class %r with abstract methods instantiated
rule.description: Used when an abstract class with `abc.ABCMeta` as metaclass has abstract methods and is instantiated.

rule.name: The first reversed() argument is not a sequence
rule.description: Used when the first argument to reversed() builtin isn't a sequence (does not implement __reversed__, nor __getitem__ and __len__

rule.name: 'continue' not supported inside 'finally' clause
rule.description: Emitted when the `continue` keyword is found inside a finally clause, which is a SyntaxError.

rule.name: An attribute defined in %s line %s hides this method
rule.description: Used when a class defines a method which is hidden by an instance attribute from an ancestor class or set by some client code.

rule.name: Access to member %r before its definition line %s
rule.description: Used when an instance member is accessed before it's actually assigned.

rule.name: Method has no argument
rule.description: Used when a method which should have the bound instance as first argument has no argument defined.

rule.name: Method should have "self" as first argument
rule.description: Used when a method has an attribute different the "self" as first argument. This is considered as an error since this is a so common convention that you shouldn't break it!

rule.name: Invalid object %r in __slots__, must contain only non empty strings
rule.description: Used when an invalid (non-string) object occurs in __slots__.

rule.name: Assigning to attribute %r not defined in class slots
rule.description: Used when assigning to an attribute not defined in the class slots.

rule.name: Invalid __slots__ object
rule.description: Used when an invalid __slots__ is found in class. Only a string, an iterable or a sequence is permitted.

rule.name: Inheriting %r, which is not a class.
rule.description: Used when a class inherits from something which is not a class.

rule.name: Inconsistent method resolution order for class %r
rule.description: Used when a class has an inconsistent method resolution order.

rule.name: Duplicate bases for class %r
rule.description: Used when a class has duplicate bases.

rule.name: __iter__ returns non-iterator
rule.description: Used when an __iter__ method returns something which is not an iterable (i.e. has no `next` method)

rule.name: The special method %r expects %s param(s), %d %s given
rule.description: Emitted when a special method was defined with an invalid number of parameters. If it has too few or too many, it might not work at all.

rule.name: __len__ does not return non-negative integer
rule.description: Used when an __len__ method returns something which is not a non-negative integer

rule.name: Unable to import %s
rule.description: Used when pylint has been unable to import a module.

rule.name: Attempted relative import beyond top-level package
rule.description: Used when a relative import tries to access too many levels in the current package.

rule.name: Using variable %r before assignment
rule.description: Used when a local variable is accessed before it's assignment.

rule.name: Undefined variable %r
rule.description: Used when an undefined variable is accessed.

rule.name: Undefined variable name %r in __all__
rule.description: Used when an undefined variable name is referenced in __all__.

rule.name: Invalid object %r in __all__, must contain only strings
rule.description: Used when an invalid (non-string) object occurs in __all__.

rule.name: No name %r in module %r
rule.description: Used when a name cannot be found in a module.

rule.name: Possible unbalanced tuple unpacking with sequence%s: left side has %d label(s), right side has %d value(s)
rule.description: Used when there is an unbalanced tuple unpacking in assignment

rule.name: Attempting to unpack a non-sequence%s
rule.description: Used when something which is not a sequence is used in an unpack assignment

rule.name: Bad except clauses order (%s)
rule.description: Used when except clauses are not in the correct order (from the more specific to the more generic). If you don't fix the order, some exceptions may not be caught by the most specific handler.

rule.name: Raising %s while only classes or instances are allowed
rule.description: Used when something which is neither a class, an instance or a string is raised (i.e. a `TypeError` will be raised).

rule.name: The raise statement is not inside an except clause
rule.description: Used when a bare raise is not used inside an except clause. This generates an error, since there are no active exceptions to be reraised. An exception to this rule is represented by a bare raise inside a finally clause, which might work, as long as an exception is raised inside the try block, but it is nevertheless a code smell that must not be relied upon.

rule.name: Raising a new style class which doesn't inherit from BaseException
rule.description: Used when a new style class which doesn't inherit from BaseException is raised.

rule.name: NotImplemented raised - should raise NotImplementedError
rule.description: Used when NotImplemented is raised instead of NotImplementedError

rule.name: Catching an exception which doesn't inherit from Exception: %s
rule.description: Used when a class which doesn't inherit from Exception is used as an exception in an except clause.

rule.name: Use of __slots__ on an old style class
rule.description: Used when an old style class uses the __slots__ attribute. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Use of super on an old style class
rule.description: Used when an old style class uses the super builtin. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Bad first argument %r given to super()
rule.description: Used when another argument than the current class is given as first argument of the super builtin.

rule.name: Missing argument to super()
rule.description: Used when the super builtin didn't receive an argument. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: %s %r has no %r member%s
rule.description: Used when a variable is accessed for an unexistent member.

rule.name: %s is not callable
rule.description: Used when an object being called has been inferred to a non callable object

rule.name: Assigning to function call which doesn't return
rule.description: Used when an assignment is done on a function call but the inferred function doesn't return anything.

rule.name: No value for argument %s in %s call
rule.description: Used when a function call passes too few arguments.

rule.name: Too many positional arguments for %s call
rule.description: Used when a function call passes too many positional arguments.

rule.name: Unexpected keyword argument %r in %s call
rule.description: Used when a function call passes a keyword argument that doesn't correspond to one of the function's parameter names.

rule.name: Argument %r passed by position and keyword in %s call
rule.description: Used when a function call would result in assigning multiple values to a function parameter, one value from a positional argument and one from a keyword argument.

rule.name: Sequence index is not an int, slice, or instance with __index__
rule.description: Used when a sequence type is indexed with an invalid type. Valid types are ints, slices, and objects with an __index__ method.

rule.name: Slice index is not an int, None, or instance with __index__
rule.description: Used when a slice index is not an integer, None, or an object with an __index__ method.

rule.name: Assigning to function call which only returns None
rule.description: Used when an assignment is done on a function call but the inferred function returns nothing but None.

rule.name: Context manager '%s' doesn't implement __enter__ and __exit__.
rule.description: Used when an instance in a with statement doesn't implement the context manager protocol(__enter__/__exit__).
Emitted when a unary operand is used on an object which does not support this type of operation
Emitted when a binary arithmetic operation between two operands is not supported.

rule.name: Got multiple values for keyword argument %r in function call
rule.description: Emitted when a function call got multiple values for a keyword.

rule.name: Non-iterable value %s is used in an iterating context
rule.description: Used when a non-iterable value is used in place where iterable is expected

rule.name: Non-mapping value %s is used in a mapping context
rule.description: Used when a non-mapping value is used in place where mapping is expected

rule.name: Value '%s' doesn't support membership test
rule.description: Emitted when an instance in membership test expression doesn't implement membership protocol (__contains__/__iter__/__getitem__)

rule.name: Value '%s' is unsubscriptable
rule.description: Emitted when a subscripted value doesn't support subscription(i.e. doesn't define __getitem__ method)

rule.name: %r does not support item assignment
rule.description: Emitted when an object does not support item assignment (i.e. doesn't define __setitem__ method)

rule.name: %r does not support item deletion
rule.description: Emitted when an object does not support item deletion (i.e. doesn't define __delitem__ method)

rule.name: Invalid metaclass %r used
rule.description: Emitted whenever we can detect that a class is using, as a metaclass, something which might be invalid for using as a metaclass.

rule.name: Unsupported logging format character %r (%#02x) at index %d
rule.description: Used when an unsupported format character is used in a logging statement format string.

rule.name: Logging format string ends in middle of conversion specifier
rule.description: Used when a logging statement format string terminates before the end of a conversion specifier.

rule.name: Too many arguments for logging format string
rule.description: Used when a logging format string is given too many arguments.

rule.name: Not enough arguments for logging format string
rule.description: Used when a logging format string is given too few arguments.

rule.name: Unsupported format character %r (%#02x) at index %d
rule.description: Used when a unsupported format character is used in a format string.

rule.name: Format string ends in middle of conversion specifier
rule.description: Used when a format string terminates before the end of a conversion specifier.

rule.name: Mixing named and unnamed conversion specifiers in format string
rule.description: Used when a format string contains both named (e.g. '%(foo)d') and unnamed (e.g. '%d') conversion specifiers. This is also used when a named conversion specifier contains * for the minimum field width and/or precision.

rule.name: Expected mapping for format string, not %s
rule.description: Used when a format string that uses named conversion specifiers is used with an argument that is not a mapping.

rule.name: Missing key %r in format string dictionary
rule.description: Used when a format string that uses named conversion specifiers is used with a dictionary that doesn't contain all the keys required by the format string.

rule.name: Too many arguments for format string
rule.description: Used when a format string that uses unnamed conversion specifiers is given too many arguments.

rule.name: Not enough arguments for format string
rule.description: Used when a format string that uses unnamed conversion specifiers is given too few arguments

rule.name: Suspicious argument in %s.%s call
rule.description: The argument to a str.{l,r,}strip call contains a duplicate character,

rule.name: print statement used
rule.description: Used when a print statement is used (`print` is a function in Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Parameter unpacking specified
rule.description: Used when parameter unpacking is specified for a function(Python 3 doesn't allow it) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Implicit unpacking of exceptions is not supported in Python 3
rule.description: Python3 will not allow implicit unpacking of exceptions in except clauses. See http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3110/ This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Use raise ErrorClass(args) instead of raise ErrorClass, args.
rule.description: Used when the alternate raise syntax 'raise foo, bar' is used instead of 'raise foo(bar)'. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Use of the `` operator
rule.description: Used when the deprecated "``" (backtick) operator is used instead of the str() function. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Use of long suffix
rule.description: Used when "l" or "L" is used to mark a long integer. This will not work in Python 3, since `int` and `long` types have merged. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Use of the <> operator
rule.description: Used when the deprecated "<>" operator is used instead of "!=". This is removed in Python 3. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Use of old octal literal
rule.description: Used when encountering the old octal syntax, removed in Python 3. To use the new syntax, prepend 0o on the number. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Import * only allowed at module level
rule.description: Used when the import star syntax is used somewhere else than the module level. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Non-ascii bytes literals not supported in 3.x
rule.description: Used when non-ascii bytes literals are found in a program. They are no longer supported in Python 3. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.
Used when an error occurred preventing the analysis of a module (unable to find it for instance).

rule.name: %s: %s
rule.description: Used when an unexpected error occurred while building the Astroid representation. This is usually accompanied by a traceback. Please report such errors !

rule.name: error while code parsing: %s
rule.description: Used when an exception occurred while building the Astroid representation which could be handled by astroid.

rule.name: Unable to check methods signature (%s / %s)
rule.description: Used when Pylint has been unable to check methods signature compatibility for an unexpected reason. Please report this kind if you don't make sense of it.

rule.name: Unable to run raw checkers on built-in module %s
rule.description: Used to inform that a built-in module has not been checked using the raw checkers.

rule.name: Unable to consider inline option %r
rule.description: Used when an inline option is either badly formatted or can't be used inside modules.

rule.name: Locally disabling %s (%s)
rule.description: Used when an inline option disables a message or a messages category.

rule.name: Locally enabling %s (%s)
rule.description: Used when an inline option enables a message or a messages category.

rule.name: Ignoring entire file
rule.description: Used to inform that the file will not be checked

rule.name: Suppressed %s (from line %d)
rule.description: A message was triggered on a line, but suppressed explicitly by a disable= comment in the file. This message is not generated for messages that are ignored due to configuration settings.

rule.name: Useless suppression of %s
rule.description: Reported when a message is explicitly disabled for a line or a block of code, but never triggered.

rule.name: Pragma "%s" is deprecated, use "%s" instead
rule.description: Some inline pylint options have been renamed or reworked, only the most recent form should be used. NOTE:skip-all is only available with pylint >= 0.26

rule.name: %s %r has not %r member%s, but source is unavailable. Consider adding this module to extension-pkg-whitelist if you want to perform analysis based on run-time introspection of living objects.
rule.description: Used when a variable is accessed for non-existent member of C extension. Due to unavailability of source static analysis is impossible, but it may be performed by introspecting living objects in run-time.

rule.name: Comparison to literal
rule.description: Used when comparing an object to a literal, which is usually what you do not want to do, since you can compare to a different literal than what was expected altogether.

rule.name: Method could be a function
rule.description: Used when a method doesn't use its bound instance, and so could be written as a function.

rule.name: Consider using a decorator instead of calling classmethod
rule.description: Used when a class method is defined without using the decorator syntax.

rule.name: Consider using a decorator instead of calling staticmethod
rule.description: Used when a static method is defined without using the decorator syntax.

rule.name: Cyclic import (%s)
rule.description: Used when a cyclic import between two or more modules is detected.

rule.name: Similar lines in %s files
rule.description: Indicates that a set of similar lines has been detected among multiple file. This usually means that the code should be refactored to avoid this duplication.

rule.name: Too many ancestors (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when class has too many parent classes, try to reduce this to get a simpler (and so easier to use) class.

rule.name: Too many instance attributes (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when class has too many instance attributes, try to reduce this to get a simpler (and so easier to use) class.

rule.name: Too few public methods (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when class has too few public methods, so be sure it's really worth it.

rule.name: Too many public methods (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when class has too many public methods, try to reduce this to get a simpler (and so easier to use) class.

rule.name: Too many return statements (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when a function or method has too many return statement, making it hard to follow.

rule.name: Too many branches (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when a function or method has too many branches, making it hard to follow.

rule.name: Too many arguments (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when a function or method takes too many arguments.

rule.name: Too many local variables (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when a function or method has too many local variables.

rule.name: Too many statements (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when a function or method has too many statements. You should then split it in smaller functions / methods.

rule.name: Too many boolean expressions in if statement (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when a if statement contains too many boolean expressions

rule.name: Consider merging these isinstance calls to isinstance(%s, (%s))
rule.description: Used when multiple consecutive isinstance calls can be merged into one.

rule.name: Too many nested blocks (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when a function or a method has too many nested blocks. This makes the code less understandable and maintainable.

rule.name: The if statement can be replaced with %s
rule.description: Used when an if statement can be replaced with 'bool(test)'.

rule.name: Redefining argument with the local name %r
rule.description: Used when a local name is redefining an argument, which might suggest a potential error. This is taken in account only for a handful of name binding operations, such as for iteration, with statement assignment and exception handler assignment.

rule.name: Unnecessary "else" after "return"
rule.description: Used in order to highlight an unnecessary block of code following an if containing a return statement. As such, it will warn when it encounters an else following a chain of ifs, all of them containing a return statement.

rule.name: Consider using ternary (%s)
rule.description: Used when one of known pre-python 2.5 ternary syntax is used.

rule.name: Boolean expression may be simplified to %s
rule.description: Emitted when redundant pre-python 2.5 ternary syntax is used.

rule.name: Either all return statements in a function should return an expression, or none of them should.
rule.description: According to PEP8, if any return statement returns an expression, any return statements where no value is returned should explicitly state this as return None, and an explicit return statement should be present at the end of the function (if reachable)

rule.name: Unreachable code
rule.description: Used when there is some code behind a "return" or "raise" statement, which will never be accessed.

rule.name: Dangerous default value %s as argument
rule.description: Used when a mutable value as list or dictionary is detected in a default value for an argument.

rule.name: Statement seems to have no effect
rule.description: Used when a statement doesn't have (or at least seems to) any effect.

rule.name: String statement has no effect
rule.description: Used when a string is used as a statement (which of course has no effect). This is a particular case of W0104 with its own message so you can easily disable it if you're using those strings as documentation, instead of comments.

rule.name: Expression "%s" is assigned to nothing
rule.description: Used when an expression that is not a function call is assigned to nothing. Probably something else was intended.

rule.name: Unnecessary pass statement
rule.description: Used when a "pass" statement that can be avoided is encountered.

rule.name: Lambda may not be necessary
rule.description: Used when the body of a lambda expression is a function call on the same argument list as the lambda itself; such lambda expressions are in all but a few cases replaceable with the function being called in the body of the lambda.

rule.name: Duplicate key %r in dictionary
rule.description: Used when a dictionary expression binds the same key multiple times.

rule.name: map/filter on lambda could be replaced by comprehension
rule.description: Used when a lambda is the first argument to "map" or "filter". It could be clearer as a list comprehension or generator expression. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Name %s will become a keyword in Python %s
rule.description: Used when assignment will become invalid in future Python release due to introducing new keyword

rule.name: Else clause on loop without a break statement
rule.description: Loops should only have an else clause if they can exit early with a break statement, otherwise the statements under else should be on the same scope as the loop itself.

rule.name: Use of exec
rule.description: Used when you use the "exec" statement (function for Python 3), to discourage its usage. That doesn't mean you cannot use it !

rule.name: Use of eval
rule.description: Used when you use the "eval" function, to discourage its usage. Consider using `ast.literal_eval` for safely evaluating strings containing Python expressions from untrusted sources.

rule.name: Following "as" with another context manager looks like a tuple.
rule.description: Emitted when a `with` statement component returns multiple values and uses name binding with `as` only for a part of those values, as in with ctx() as a, b. This can be misleading, since it's not clear if the context manager returns a tuple or if the node without a name binding is another context manager.

rule.name: Using a conditional statement with a constant value
rule.description: Emitted when a conditional statement (If or ternary if) uses a constant value for its test. This might not be what the user intended to do.

rule.name: %s statement in finally block may swallow exception
rule.description: Used when a break or a return statement is found inside the finally clause of a try...finally block: the exceptions raised in the try clause will be silently swallowed instead of being re-raised.

rule.name: Assert called on a 2-uple. Did you mean 'assert x,y'?
rule.description: A call of assert on a tuple will always evaluate to true if the tuple is not empty, and will always evaluate to false if it is.

rule.name: Attribute %r defined outside __init__
rule.description: Used when an instance attribute is defined outside the __init__ method.

rule.name: Static method with %r as first argument
rule.description: Used when a static method has "self" or a value specified in valid- classmethod-first-arg option or valid-metaclass-classmethod-first-arg option as first argument.

rule.name: Access to a protected member %s of a client class
rule.description: Used when a protected member (i.e. class member with a name beginning with an underscore) is access outside the class or a descendant of the class where it's defined.

rule.name: Parameters differ from %s %r method
rule.description: Used when a method has a different number of arguments than in the implemented interface or in an overridden method.

rule.name: Signature differs from %s %r method
rule.description: Used when a method signature is different than in the implemented interface or in an overridden method.

rule.name: Method %r is abstract in class %r but is not overridden
rule.description: Used when an abstract method (i.e. raise NotImplementedError) is not overridden in concrete class.

rule.name: __init__ method from base class %r is not called
rule.description: Used when an ancestor class method has an __init__ method which is not called by a derived class.

rule.name: Class has no __init__ method
rule.description: Used when a class has no __init__ method, neither its parent classes.

rule.name: __init__ method from a non direct base class %r is called
rule.description: Used when an __init__ method is called on a class which is not in the direct ancestors for the analysed class.

rule.name: Useless super delegation in method %r
rule.description: Used whenever we can detect that an overridden method is useless, relying on super() delegation to do the same thing as another method from the MRO.

rule.name: Unnecessary semicolon
rule.description: Used when a statement is ended by a semi-colon (";"), which isn't necessary (that's python, not C ;).

rule.name: Bad indentation. Found %s %s, expected %s
rule.description: Used when an unexpected number of indentation's tabulations or spaces has been found.

rule.name: Found indentation with %ss instead of %ss
rule.description: Used when there are some mixed tabs and spaces in a module.

rule.name: Use of "l" as long integer identifier
rule.description: Used when a lower case "l" is used to mark a long integer. You should use a upper case "L" since the letter "l" looks too much like the digit "1" This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Wildcard import %s
rule.description: Used when `from module import *` is detected.

rule.name: Uses of a deprecated module %r
rule.description: Used a module marked as deprecated is imported.

rule.name: Relative import %r, should be %r
rule.description: Used when an import relative to the package directory is detected. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Reimport %r (imported line %s)
rule.description: Used when a module is reimported multiple times.

rule.name: Module import itself
rule.description: Used when a module is importing itself.

rule.name: __future__ import is not the first non docstring statement
rule.description: Python 2.5 and greater require __future__ import to be the first non docstring statement in the module.
Used when a warning note as FIXME or XXX is detected.

rule.name: Cannot decode using encoding "%s", unexpected byte at position %d
rule.description: Used when a source line cannot be decoded using the specified source file encoding. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Global variable %r undefined at the module level
rule.description: Used when a variable is defined through the "global" statement but the variable is not defined in the module scope.

rule.name: Using global for %r but no assignment is done
rule.description: Used when a variable is defined through the "global" statement but no assignment to this variable is done.

rule.name: Using the global statement
rule.description: Used when you use the "global" statement to update a global variable. Pylint just try to discourage this usage. That doesn't mean you cannot use it !

rule.name: Using the global statement at the module level
rule.description: Used when you use the "global" statement at the module level since it has no effect

rule.name: Unused %s
rule.description: Used when an imported module or variable is not used.

rule.name: Unused variable %r
rule.description: Used when a variable is defined but not used.

rule.name: Unused argument %r
rule.description: Used when a function or method argument is not used.

rule.name: Unused import %s from wildcard import
rule.description: Used when an imported module or variable is not used from a `'from X import *'` style import.

rule.name: Redefining name %r from outer scope (line %s)
rule.description: Used when a variable's name hides a name defined in the outer scope.

rule.name: Redefining built-in %r
rule.description: Used when a variable or function override a built-in.

rule.name: Redefining name %r from %s in exception handler
rule.description: Used when an exception handler assigns the exception to an existing name

rule.name: Using possibly undefined loop variable %r
rule.description: Used when an loop variable (i.e. defined by a for loop or a list comprehension or a generator expression) is used outside the loop.

rule.name: Cell variable %s defined in loop
rule.description: A variable used in a closure is defined in a loop. This will result in all closures using the same value for the closed-over variable.

rule.name: No exception type(s) specified
rule.description: Used when an except clause doesn't specify exceptions type to catch.

rule.name: Catching too general exception %s
rule.description: Used when an except catches a too general exception, possibly burying unrelated errors.

rule.name: Catching previously caught exception type %s
rule.description: Used when an except catches a type that was already caught by a previous handler.

rule.name: Exception doesn't inherit from standard "Exception" class
rule.description: Used when a custom exception class is raised but doesn't inherit from the builtin "Exception" class. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Exception to catch is the result of a binary "%s" operation
rule.description: Used when the exception to catch is of the form "except A or B:". If intending to catch multiple, rewrite as "except (A, B):"

rule.name: Exception arguments suggest string formatting might be intended
rule.description: Used when passing multiple arguments to an exception constructor, the first of them a string literal containing what appears to be placeholders intended for formatting

rule.name: Use of "property" on an old style class
rule.description: Used when Pylint detect the use of the builtin "property" on an old style class while this is relying on new style classes features. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Keyword argument before variable positional arguments list in the definition of %s function
rule.description: When defining a keyword argument before variable positional arguments, one can end up in having multiple values passed for the aforementioned parameter in case the method is called with keyword arguments.

rule.name: Specify string format arguments as logging function parameters
rule.description: Used when a logging statement has a call form of "logging.<logging method>(format_string % (format_args...))". Such calls should leave string interpolation to the logging method itself and be written "logging.<logging method>(format_string, format_args...)" so that the program may avoid incurring the cost of the interpolation in those cases in which no message will be logged. For more, see http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0282/.

rule.name: Use % formatting in logging functions and pass the % parameters as arguments
rule.description: Used when a logging statement has a call form of "logging.<logging method>(format_string.format(format_args...))". Such calls should use % formatting instead, but leave interpolation to the logging function by passing the parameters as arguments.

rule.name: Format string dictionary key should be a string, not %s
rule.description: Used when a format string that uses named conversion specifiers is used with a dictionary whose keys are not all strings.

rule.name: Unused key %r in format string dictionary
rule.description: Used when a format string that uses named conversion specifiers is used with a dictionary that contains keys not required by the format string.

rule.name: Invalid format string
rule.description: Used when a PEP 3101 format string is invalid. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 2.7.

rule.name: Missing keyword argument %r for format string
rule.description: Used when a PEP 3101 format string that uses named fields doesn't receive one or more required keywords. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 2.7.

rule.name: Unused format argument %r
rule.description: Used when a PEP 3101 format string that uses named fields is used with an argument that is not required by the format string. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 2.7.

rule.name: Format string contains both automatic field numbering and manual field specification
rule.description: Used when a PEP 3101 format string contains both automatic field numbering (e.g. '{}') and manual field specification (e.g. '{0}'). This message can't be emitted when using Python < 2.7.

rule.name: Missing format attribute %r in format specifier %r
rule.description: Used when a PEP 3101 format string uses an attribute specifier ({0.length}), but the argument passed for formatting doesn't have that attribute. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 2.7.

rule.name: Using invalid lookup key %r in format specifier %r
rule.description: Used when a PEP 3101 format string uses a lookup specifier ({a[1]}), but the argument passed for formatting doesn't contain or doesn't have that key as an attribute. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 2.7.

rule.name: Anomalous backslash in string: '%s'. String constant might be missing an r prefix.
rule.description: Used when a backslash is in a literal string but not as an escape.

rule.name: Anomalous Unicode escape in byte string: '%s'. String constant might be missing an r or u prefix.
rule.description: Used when an escape like \u is encountered in a byte string where it has no effect.

rule.name: "%s" is not a valid mode for open.
rule.description: Python supports: r, w, a[, x] modes with b, +, and U (only with r) options. See http://docs.python.org/2/library/functions.html#open

rule.name: Using datetime.time in a boolean context.
rule.description: Using datetime.time in a boolean context can hide subtle bugs when the time they represent matches midnight UTC. This behaviour was fixed in Python 3.5. See http://bugs.python.org/issue13936 for reference. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.5.

rule.name: Redundant use of %s with constant value %r
rule.description: The first argument of assertTrue and assertFalse is a condition. If a constant is passed as parameter, that condition will be always true. In this case a warning should be emitted.

rule.name: Using deprecated method %s()
rule.description: The method is marked as deprecated and will be removed in a future version of Python. Consider looking for an alternative in the documentation.

rule.name: threading.Thread needs the target function
rule.description: The warning is emitted when a threading.Thread class is instantiated without the target function being passed. By default, the first parameter is the group param, not the target param.

rule.name: Using copy.copy(os.environ). Use os.environ.copy() instead.
rule.description: os.environ is not a dict object but proxy object, so shallow copy has still effects on original object. See https://bugs.python.org/issue15373 for reference.

rule.name: apply built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the apply built-in function is referenced (missing from Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: basestring built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the basestring built-in function is referenced (missing from Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: buffer built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the buffer built-in function is referenced (missing from Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: cmp built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the cmp built-in function is referenced (missing from Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: coerce built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the coerce built-in function is referenced (missing from Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: execfile built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the execfile built-in function is referenced (missing from Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: file built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the file built-in function is referenced (missing from Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: long built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the long built-in function is referenced (missing from Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: raw_input built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the raw_input built-in function is referenced (missing from Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: reduce built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the reduce built-in function is referenced (missing from Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: StandardError built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the StandardError built-in function is referenced (missing from Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: unicode built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the unicode built-in function is referenced (missing from Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: xrange built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the xrange built-in function is referenced (missing from Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: __coerce__ method defined
rule.description: Used when a __coerce__ method is defined (method is not used by Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: __delslice__ method defined
rule.description: Used when a __delslice__ method is defined (method is not used by Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: __getslice__ method defined
rule.description: Used when a __getslice__ method is defined (method is not used by Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: __setslice__ method defined
rule.description: Used when a __setslice__ method is defined (method is not used by Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: import missing `from __future__ import absolute_import`
rule.description: Used when an import is not accompanied by ``from __future__ import absolute_import`` (default behaviour in Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: division w/o __future__ statement
rule.description: Used for non-floor division w/o a float literal or ``from __future__ import division`` (Python 3 returns a float for int division unconditionally) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Calling a dict.iter*() method
rule.description: Used for calls to dict.iterkeys(), itervalues() or iteritems() (Python 3 lacks these methods) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Calling a dict.view*() method
rule.description: Used for calls to dict.viewkeys(), viewvalues() or viewitems() (Python 3 lacks these methods) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Called a next() method on an object
rule.description: Used when an object's next() method is called (Python 3 uses the next() built- in function) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Assigning to a class's __metaclass__ attribute
rule.description: Used when a metaclass is specified by assigning to __metaclass__ (Python 3 specifies the metaclass as a class statement argument) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Indexing exceptions will not work on Python 3
rule.description: Indexing exceptions will not work on Python 3. Use `exception.args[index]` instead. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Raising a string exception
rule.description: Used when a string exception is raised. This will not work on Python 3. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: reload built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the reload built-in function is referenced (missing from Python 3). You can use instead imp.reload or importlib.reload. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: __oct__ method defined
rule.description: Used when a __oct__ method is defined (method is not used by Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: __hex__ method defined
rule.description: Used when a __hex__ method is defined (method is not used by Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: __nonzero__ method defined
rule.description: Used when a __nonzero__ method is defined (method is not used by Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: __cmp__ method defined
rule.description: Used when a __cmp__ method is defined (method is not used by Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: input built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the input built-in is referenced (backwards-incompatible semantics in Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: round built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the round built-in is referenced (backwards-incompatible semantics in Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: intern built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the intern built-in is referenced (Moved to sys.intern in Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: unichr built-in referenced
rule.description: Used when the unichr built-in is referenced (Use chr in Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: map built-in referenced when not iterating
rule.description: Used when the map built-in is referenced in a non-iterating context (returns an iterator in Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: zip built-in referenced when not iterating
rule.description: Used when the zip built-in is referenced in a non-iterating context (returns an iterator in Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: range built-in referenced when not iterating
rule.description: Used when the range built-in is referenced in a non-iterating context (returns an iterator in Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: filter built-in referenced when not iterating
rule.description: Used when the filter built-in is referenced in a non-iterating context (returns an iterator in Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Using the cmp argument for list.sort / sorted
rule.description: Using the cmp argument for list.sort or the sorted builtin should be avoided, since it was removed in Python 3. Using either `key` or `functools.cmp_to_key` should be preferred. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Implementing __eq__ without also implementing __hash__
rule.description: Used when a class implements __eq__ but not __hash__. In Python 2, objects get object.__hash__ as the default implementation, in Python 3 objects get None as their default __hash__ implementation if they also implement __eq__. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: __div__ method defined
rule.description: Used when a __div__ method is defined. Using `__truediv__` and setting__div__ = __truediv__ should be preferred.(method is not used by Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: __idiv__ method defined
rule.description: Used when a __idiv__ method is defined. Using `__itruediv__` and setting__idiv__ = __itruediv__ should be preferred.(method is not used by Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: __rdiv__ method defined
rule.description: Used when a __rdiv__ method is defined. Using `__rtruediv__` and setting__rdiv__ = __rtruediv__ should be preferred.(method is not used by Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Exception.message removed in Python 3
rule.description: Used when the message attribute is accessed on an Exception. Use str(exception) instead. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: non-text encoding used in str.decode
rule.description: Used when using str.encode or str.decode with a non-text encoding. Use codecs module to handle arbitrary codecs. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: sys.maxint removed in Python 3
rule.description: Used when accessing sys.maxint. Use sys.maxsize instead. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Accessing a deprecated function on the string module
rule.description: Used when accessing a string function that has been deprecated in Python 3. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Using str.translate with deprecated deletechars parameters
rule.description: Used when using the deprecated deletechars parameters from str.translate. Usere.sub to remove the desired characters This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Accessing a deprecated function on the itertools module
rule.description: Used when accessing a function on itertools that has been removed in Python 3. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: Accessing a deprecated fields on the types module
rule.description: Used when accessing a field on types that has been removed in Python 3. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: next method defined
rule.description: Used when a next method is defined that would be an iterator in Python 2 but is treated as a normal function in Python 3. This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: dict.items referenced when not iterating
rule.description: Used when dict.items is referenced in a non-iterating context (returns an iterator in Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: dict.keys referenced when not iterating
rule.description: Used when dict.keys is referenced in a non-iterating context (returns an iterator in Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.

rule.name: dict.values referenced when not iterating
rule.description: Used when dict.values is referenced in a non-iterating context (returns an iterator in Python 3) This message can't be emitted when using Python >= 3.0.
